title: With DC Terrell Williams out, who will be calling defensive plays for Patriots vs. Dolphins?
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Zak Kuhr, inside linebackers coach, will call defensive plays for the Patriots against the Dolphins.
Terrell Williams is absent due to an undisclosed health matter; Mike Vrabel won't update until next week.
Kuhr previously filled in as defensive playcaller during preseason when Williams was also unavailable.

title: Boston activist Monica Cannon-Grant to plead guilty in federal fraud case
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Monica Cannon-Grant plans to plead guilty in federal fraud case before her trial set for October.
The charges include wire fraud, mail fraud, and lying on a mortgage application, totaling 27 counts.
Prosecutors allege over $100,000 in donor funds were misused for personal expenses by Cannon-Grant and her late husband.

title: Here’s what we know about Tyler Robinson, Charlie Kirk’s alleged assassin
author: The Associated Press
bullets: Tyler James Robinson, 22, was arrested on suspicion of killing Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University.
Robinson, a student at Dixie Technical College, reportedly discussed obtaining a gun on Discord prior to the incident.
Robinson's family reported he recently became 'more political' and viewed Kirk as spreading hate, per charging documents.

title: 7 things to know about a pivotal Red Sox-Yankees series
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Red Sox and Yankees compete for the top American League wild-card spot in a crucial series at Fenway Park.
Red Sox pitcher Brayan Bello has excelled against the Yankees this year, not allowing a run in 14 innings.
The Yankees lead MLB in home runs this season, with 249 homers, crucial to their 69-44 record in those games.

title: Winthrop loses $1.2M in climate grants over MBTA Communities Act noncompliance
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Winthrop lost $1.2 million in climate grants due to noncompliance with the MBTA Communities Act.
The funds were intended for flood mitigation projects in the Morton and Fisherman's Bend areas.
A zoning proposal to comply with the MBTA Communities Act failed after a 4-4 Town Council vote.

title: Healey orders flags at state buildings flown at half-staff to honor Charlie Kirk
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Gov. Maura Healey ordered flags at Massachusetts state buildings to half-staff until Sept. 14 to honor Charlie Kirk.
Charlie Kirk was fatally shot during an event at Utah Valley University, prompting a proclamation from President Donald Trump.
Tyler Robinson, 22, was arrested for the shooting; officials noted he had become politically involved prior to the incident.

title: A family-friendly guide to apple picking in New England
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Honey Pot Hill Orchards in Stow, Massachusetts offers 30 apple varieties, mazes, farm animals, and cider doughnuts.
Treworgy Family Orchards in Levant, Maine was named best for its pumpkin patch and corn maze by USA Today.
Lyman Orchards in Middlefield, Connecticut hosts a free AutumnFest with a pie run, pumpkin bowling, and live music.

title: Judge tosses ordinance limiting tear gas, rubber bullet use by Boston police
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Judge Jackie Cowin ruled a Boston city ordinance limiting police use of tear gas and rubber bullets is invalid.
The ordinance required police supervisors to witness violence, exhaust other methods, and issue warnings before using crowd-control measures.
The court ruled the City Council overstepped its authority, as weapon deployment decisions are reserved for the Police Commissioner.

title: Did a Brooklyn couple kill a neighborâ€™s trees for a better view in Maine?
author: New York Times Service
bullets: Maine's Board of Pesticides Control accuses Stephen Antonson and Kathleen Hackett of poisoning a neighbor's trees for a harbor view.
The couple, associated with Martha Stewart, bought a summer house in Rockport, Maine, in 2017 with obstructed views.
Tests revealed herbicidal poison in bore holes of trees on Ruth Graham's property, prompting accusations against the couple.

title: Pharma giant with large Mass. footprint to slash 9,000 jobs globally
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Novo Nordisk announced plans to cut 9,000 jobs worldwide by 2026 due to organizational complexity and cost issues.
The Danish company employs 450 people in Massachusetts but has not specified local job impacts in Boston.
Novo Nordisk expects the job cuts to result in $1.25 billion annual savings, focusing on diabetes and obesity growth opportunities.
